author: ghost
body:
# Summary of the new feature/enhancement

Windows powershell and cmd have an option in the settings menu to set the terminal to translucent. This is very important to me to watch programming talks, podcasts, and star trek while I am coding. It also helps because when I am copying over a command from stack overflow or somesuch to powershell I can see the command in the other window.

On my copy of windows pro 10.0.17763 build 17763 the terminal does not remember the setting for translucency when I close and open my terminal. That means each time I log in I have to set my translucency manually.

# Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

Add a floating point number in storage that contains the last known percentage for transparency. This way when the terminal opens it checks this number and remembers what I had it set to, thus removing a step when I log in.

comments.author: vexx32
comments.body: To my memory, there is both a `Properties` option _and_ and `Defaults` option that allow you to change transparency. The former only sets it for the current session, whereas the latter should change the stored defaults and persist between sessions. 😄

comments.author: mklement0
comments.body:
As an aside, @johnmorrisbeck: In the future, can you please add a summary of your request in the _title_ and also remove the instructions that come with the issue template?

To add to @vexx32's comment: if you start your PowerShell instance from a shortcut file, changing the opacity (via `Properties`, not `Defaults`) automatically sticks for future invocations via that shortcut file.

comments.author: SimonWahlin
comments.body: Also as a quick note, you can change the transparency really quick by holding down CTRL+SHIFT while scrolling, this is great for quickly moving back and fourth between different transparency levels.
